result.execSummary:
The defendant Dean James Kentopp was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
With Huber privileges consistent with the rules of the jail while the inmate maintains a minimum security status. The defendant, at the discretion of the Sheriff, may perform community service work as an inmate worker in the county jail and shall earn statutory good time for same. 

Defendant shall contact the Washington County Jail within 3 days for purposes of supplying a biological specimen for DNA analysis. Defendant has the right to request expungement of DNA analysis in writing through the Department of Justice.
Consecutive to: any other sentence defendant is serving.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Dean James Kentopp

records.addlTxt: Washington County Sheriff's Office Jail Disposition of Prisoners

Defendant Dean James Kentopp appeared by video from Washington CO Jail, in custody. Prosecuting attorney Mandy A. Schepper and Atty Jeannette Corbett in court for the State of Wisconsin. Defendant not eligible for State Public Defender. Def wishes to resolve today. Def pleads guilty; is convicted and sentenced.
No contact with CJN or her residence or any place where she is employed.

Defendant Dean James Kentopp appeared by video from Washington CO Jail, in custody. Prosecuting attorney Mark David Bensen in court for the State of Wisconsin. Def given complaint, advised of charges, penalties and rights, and probable cause found. Def on PO hold. Def waives counsel to PT with DA; wants to resolve. State needs time to comply with victim rights  before case returns to court. Plea hearing scheduled for October 12, 2022 at 08:15 am.
Plea hearing on October 12, 2022 at 08:15 am.
